titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: The brilliant weather continues, & the good news from France. Sounds of gun–firing went along with the rattle of the aeroplanes to keep the War always in our minds. I wrote to Linetta suggesting a possible scheme of my lecture on "The Anglican Version of X
" for King's College in October. I w
start by picturing the ordinary Englishman's religion in the year 1500, and comparing it with what it had become in 1600, in 1700, in 1800, and in 1900. I w
then distinguish the salient notes of the new "Anglicanism". It was insular, Biblical, secular, individualistic. Severally these "notes" were most apparent at the several dates. Then I w
inquire whether any, and if so what, principles were implicit in these "notes": &, finally, ask what future lay before this version of Christianity.
writes in reply to a letter in which I had asked, half playfully, how he w
